messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Saotome women
messages.msgSnippet: I have to thank Rich for agreeing to a several-month embargo on the publication of this research.  We felt that going to press early in the second quarter was
messages.messageBody:
I have to thank Rich for agreeing to a several-month embargo on the publication of this research. We felt that going to press early in the second quarter was crucial given the nature of the findings.

Jim



Thanks to the research by Jim and others, we have made
a major discovery in relation to the origins and makers of
Saotome tsuba, contrary to the standard lineage given in
Japanese sources.

Saotome tsuba are now known to have been made by
a group of women tsuba makers; the so-called "Rice
Planting Women". These were a group of women who
during the season were engaged in the planting of rice,
but who during the off season made tsuba as a means
of enhancing their incomes. These women tsuba makers
were excellent metal workers making well wrought tsuba
plates that they sold either as finished products or to
other schools of tsuba makers to embellish in that
schools particular style. This is perhaps the only
known instance where women composed a major
school of tsuba makers.

Thanks to Jim and others for their research in
bringing this important information to light.

Rich S
April 1, 2004 :-)



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, samurai@x wrote:
>
> Is there going to be an article published illustrating the
rationale?
> The conclusion is very interesting, but I'd love to hear how it came
to
> be arrived at.
>
> - darcy

Darcy -

No article planned, but you can get the rationale by
entering "saotome" in the search engine at:

http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/jwb/wwwjdic?1KJ


Also a picture of a really rare Saotome plate with a
self portrait of the maker (possibly the only such
plate known). The zogan is probably a later Nara
addition. Which also proves the Saotome women sold
their stuff to other folks :-)

http://home.earthlink.net/~ttstein/joke.jpg

Rich S

messages.subject: Saotome women
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks to the research by Jim and others, we have made a major discovery in relation to the origins and makers of Saotome tsuba, contrary to the standard
messages.messageBody:
Thanks to the research by Jim and others, we have made
a major discovery in relation to the origins and makers of
Saotome tsuba, contrary to the standard lineage given in
Japanese sources.

Saotome tsuba are now known to have been made by
a group of women tsuba makers; the so-called "Rice
Planting Women". These were a group of women who
during the season were engaged in the planting of rice,
but who during the off season made tsuba as a means
of enhancing their incomes. These women tsuba makers
were excellent metal workers making well wrought tsuba
plates that they sold either as finished products or to
other schools of tsuba makers to embellish in that
schools particular style. This is perhaps the only
known instance where women composed a major
school of tsuba makers.

Thanks to Jim and others for their research in
bringing this important information to light.

Rich S
April 1, 2004 :-)
